newsitem.title: FRANCE: French industrial output leaps in July/August.
newsitem.headline: French industrial output leaps in July/August.

text.p: French industrial production rose strongly in July and August, helped by a surge in car output as people rushed to cash in on a government car sales incentive which expired at the end of September.

National statistics institute INSEE said industrial output excluding energy, agri-food business and construction rose 2.9 percent in the two-month period from June after rising 0.3 percent in June compared to May. INSEE considers this figure the best gauge of manufacturing output in France.
Manufacturing output was down 0.3 percent year-on-year.
Industrial production, including energy and agri-food, but excluding construction, rose 1.9 percent from June and was unchnanged year-on-year.
INSEE said most of the rise was due to a leap in car production, which rose 8.1 percent in July/August after a 4.4 percent rise in June.
Sean Shepley, international economist at CS First Boston, said he was sceptical about whether the industrial production figures were indicative of any underlying strength.
"They will be helpful for the government in trying to persuade people things are getting better," he said.
"It shows there was a bit more activity, but it's only one figure. I'd prefer to see a trend," a futures trader at a French bank said.
Consumer goods production rose a sharp 3.3 percent in the period, while semi-finished goods production rose 2.5 percent, helped by an increase in output in car-related metals and electronics.
INSEE revised June industial production figures to show a drop excluding construction of 0.4 percent and a manufacturing ouput rise of 0.3 percent.
INSEE had originally reported in July that June industrial output excluding construction fell 0.2 percent from May while manufacturing output was reported up 0.5 percent.
